summary: in 2014, there were 3.2 billion people at risk of being infected with malaria. 198 million cases of malaria and 584,000 deaths occurred globally in 2013. malaria remains a serious public health problem in china. experimental research reported in this study has been performed with the approval of the ethics committee of Zhejiang Provincial Center for Disease Control and Prevention. human research was carried out in compliance with the Helsinki Declaration. all participants provide their written informed consent to participate in this study. number of malaria cases increased from 2005 to 2007 and then peaked in 2007, and then the number of malaria cases decreased from 2007 to 2011. there were no indigenous cases in these 3 years. malaria cases were reported in all 11 cities of Zhejiang Province from 2005 to 2014. malaria cases from Ningbo, Jinhua, Taizhou, Wenzhou, and Hangzhou accounted for 79% of cases. from 2005 to 2009, no information about the origins of imported cases was investigated. IQRs: 3–8 days; range: 0–332 days. median time from illness onset to confirmation malaria decreased from 2005 to 2014. majority of malaria cases from 2005 to 2011 were imported and all cases from 2012 to 2014 were imported. many departments collaborated with each other to eliminate malaria in Zhejiang province. the control and management of infection source were enhanced. cases were reported, treated, and managed soon after the confirmation. cases of P. vivax malaria often resulted in increased hospitalizations, severe disease, and death than previously expected. the majority of malaria cases during 2005–2011 occurred yearly between May and October, but the number of malaria cases in different months during 2012–2014 was similar. the number of imported cases was relative to the frequency of travel and trade to malaria-endemic areas. the median time from illness onset to confirmation of all cases was 5 days. this may be related to health education to international traveler.
